questions.text: Needle-shaped crystals negatively birefringent on polarized microscopy is characteristic of which crystal-associated arthropathy?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. CPPD: CPPD, or pseudogout, is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints. These crystals are rhomboid-shaped and are positively birefringent under polarized light.
  • • Option B. CPPD:
  • • Option C. Neuropathic arthropathy: Neuropathic arthropathy is associated with nerve damage, often seen in conditions such as diabetes. It is characterized by joint damage and deformities due to the loss of sensation and proprioception. Crystal deposition is not a typical feature of neuropathic arthropathy.
  • • Option C. Neuropathic arthropathy:
  • • Option D. Hemophilic arthropathy: Hemophilic arthropathy is a condition that affects joints in individuals with hemophilia. It is characterized by recurrent bleeding into the joints, leading to chronic inflammation, synovial hypertrophy, and joint damage. Crystals are not typically associated with hemophilic arthropathy.
  • • Option D. Hemophilic arthropathy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints. These crystals appear as needle-shaped and are negatively birefringent when viewed under polarized light.
  • ➤ Gout is a form of inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in the joints.
  • ➤ These crystals appear as needle-shaped and are negatively birefringent when viewed under polarized light.

questions.text: Joint erosion is not a feature in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Systemic Lupus Erythematosus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Gout. Gout is characterized by the deposition of urate crystals in joints, leading to inflammation. If left untreated and chronic, gout can cause joint damage and erosion over time.
  • • Option B. Gout.
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis. Joint erosion is a prominent feature of rheumatoid arthritis. Chronic inflammation in RA can lead to the destruction of cartilage and bone in affected joints.
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option D. Psoriasis. Psoriatic arthritis, associated with psoriasis, can cause joint damage, including joint erosion. Joint involvement in psoriatic arthritis may lead to erosive changes similar to those seen in rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option D. Psoriasis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.
  • ➤ While joint involvement can occur in SLE, erosive changes are generally less common compared to conditions like rheumatoid arthritis or psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: The most commonly involved joint in pseudogout is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Knee

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Great toe . While pseudogout can affect various joints, the great toe is not the most commonly involved joint. Great toe is most commonly involved in the gout.
  • • Option B. Great toe
  • • Option C. Hip. The hip joint can be affected by pseudogout, but it is not the most commonly involved joint.
  • • Option C. Hip.
  • • Option D. Elbow. The elbow joint can also be affected by pseudogout, but, similar to the hip, it is not the most commonly involved joint.
  • • Option D. Elbow.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudogout can affect various joints, the knee is the most commonly involved joint. The knee joint is often a primary site of crystal deposition and subsequent inflammation in pseudogout.
  • ➤ Pseudogout can affect various joints, the knee is the most commonly involved joint.
  • ➤ The knee joint is often a primary site of crystal deposition and subsequent inflammation in pseudogout.

questions.text: Multiple loose bodies are seen maximum in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Synovial chondromatosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteochondritis dissecans. This condition involves the separation of a fragment of bone and cartilage from the underlying bone. While it can result in loose bodies, they are typically not numerous.
  • • Option A.
  • • Osteochondritis dissecans.
  • • Option C. Osteoarthritis . Osteoarthritis is characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in joints, but it typically doesn't result in multiple loose bodies.
  • • Option C.
  • • Osteoarthritis
  • • Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis . Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune condition that primarily affects the synovial lining of joints. While it can lead to joint damage, it's less likely to result in multiple loose bodies compared to synovial chondromatosis.
  • • Option D.
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of multiple loose bodies is most commonly associated with synovial chondromatosis. It involves the synovium, the lining of the joint, which undergoes metaplasia and forms cartilaginous nodules that may detach and become free-floating within the joint space.
  • ➤ The presence of multiple loose bodies is most commonly associated with synovial chondromatosis.
  • ➤ It involves the synovium, the lining of the joint, which undergoes metaplasia and forms cartilaginous nodules that may detach and become free-floating within the joint space.

questions.text: Epiphyseal enlargement is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Rickets . Rickets is a condition caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, leading to impaired mineralization of growing bones. In rickets, the epiphyses of the long bones may become enlarged, leading to deformities.
  • • Option A. Rickets
  • • Option B. Haemophilia. Hemophilia is a bleeding disorder, and its effects on bones are often related to bleeding into joints, which can lead to joint damage and deformities. Epiphyseal enlargement typical feature of hemophilia.
  • • Option B. Haemophilia.
  • • Option C. Septic Arthritis . Septic arthritis is an infection of the joint, and it may lead to destruction of the joint structures. Epiphyseal enlargement is characteristic of septic enlargement.
  • • Option C. Septic Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Epiphyseal enlargement refers to an abnormal increase in the size of the epiphysis, which is the rounded end of a long bone that forms part of a joint. Epiphyseal enlargement is seen in rickets, hemophilia and septic arthritis.
  • ➤ Epiphyseal enlargement refers to an abnormal increase in the size of the epiphysis, which is the rounded end of a long bone that forms part of a joint.
  • ➤ Epiphyseal enlargement is seen in rickets, hemophilia and septic arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not affected in gout?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Muscle

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Skin . In advanced cases of gout, tophi may develop under the skin. Tophi are nodular masses composed of urate crystals and can be found in various tissues, including the skin. These tophi can lead to skin changes, such as nodules or lumps, and may be visible or palpable.
  • • Option B. Skin
  • • Option C. Cartilage. Gout can affect cartilage indirectly by causing joint damage. Urate crystals can accumulate in the joints, leading to inflammation and damage to the cartilage over time. Joint erosion and deformities may occur as a result of chronic gout, especially if the condition is not adequately managed. They most commonly affect the cartilage of the ear i.e., the pinna.
  • • Option C. Cartilage.
  • • Option D. Tendon. Tendons around the joints can be affected in gout. Urate crystal deposition in and around the tendons can lead to inflammation, a condition known as tenosynovitis . This inflammation can cause pain, swelling, and difficulty with joint movement.
  • • Option D. Tendon.
  • • tenosynovitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Muscle tissue is not a primary target of urate crystal deposition in gout. The condition can affect the skin (through tophi), cartilage (indirectly causing joint damage), and tendons (leading to tenosynovitis).
  • ➤ Muscle tissue is not a primary target of urate crystal deposition in gout.
  • ➤ The condition can affect the skin (through tophi), cartilage (indirectly causing joint damage), and tendons (leading to tenosynovitis).

questions.text: Calcification of menisci is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pseudogout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Hyperparathyroidism. Calcification of menisci can be seen in hyperparathyroidism but pseudogut is the commonest cause.
  • • Option A. Hyperparathyroidism.
  • • Option C. Renal osteodystrophy. Renal osteodystrophy is a bone disorder that occurs in the context of chronic kidney disease (CKD). It is characterized by abnormalities in bone metabolism and mineralization due to impaired kidney function. While renal osteodystrophy can affect bone density and structure, calcification of the menisci is not a common feature of this condition.
  • • Option C. Renal osteodystrophy.
  • • Option D. Acromegaly. Acromegaly is a disorder caused by excessive growth hormone production, often due to a pituitary tumor. Calcification of menisci can be seen in acromegaly but it is less common than pseudogout.
  • • Option D. Acromegaly.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcification of menisci is seen in pseudogout. It can be seen in hyperthyroidism and acromegaly also but pseudogout is the commonest cause.
  • ➤ Calcification of menisci is seen in pseudogout.
  • ➤ It can be seen in hyperthyroidism and acromegaly also but pseudogout is the commonest cause.

questions.text: In uncemented arthroplasty of the hip, the stem remains attached to the bone by:

options.label: A
options.text: Bone Ingrowth/overgrowth over the surface of the stem

options.label: B
options.text: Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone

options.label: C
options.text: Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal

options.label: D
options.text: Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem

questions.correct_answer: A. Bone Ingrowth/overgrowth over the surface of the stem
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bone ingrowth/overgrowth over the surface of the stem

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone . While the concept of mechanical bonding is related to achieving stability between the stem and bone, in uncemented arthroplasty, the primary mechanism is bone ingrowth. Mechanical stability is an important aspect, but it is secondary to achieving biological fixation through bone ingrowth.
  • • Option B. Mechanical bonding between the stem and bone
  • • Option C. Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal. Press fitting involves placing the implant into the bone without using cement, relying on the interference fit between the implant and the bone. While press fitting is a component of uncemented arthroplasty, the long-term stability is mainly achieved through bone ingrowth onto the implant surface.
  • • Option C. Press fitting of the stem in the tight canal.
  • • Option D. Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem. Adhesion is not the primary mechanism for fixation in uncemented arthroplasty. The goal is to promote biological fixation through bone ingrowth, where bone tissue grows onto the surface of the implant.
  • • Option D.
  • • Adhesion between the stem and bone due to adhesive properties of the stem.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In uncemented hip arthroplasty, the goal is for the bone to grow onto the surface of the implant, creating a stable and durable fixation. This process is known as osseointegration . Bone ingrowth helps provide long-term stability and support for the artificial hip joint.
  • ➤ In uncemented hip arthroplasty, the goal is for the bone to grow onto the surface of the implant, creating a stable and durable fixation. This process is known as osseointegration .
  • ➤ osseointegration
  • ➤ Bone ingrowth helps provide long-term stability and support for the artificial hip joint.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female patient presents with one-year history of anterior knee pain on climbing stairs. On examination, crepitus was present. There was severe restriction of movements beyond 110 degrees. Examination of hip and back was normal. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Psoriatic arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Symptoms can involve various joints and may present with pain, swelling, and morning stiffness. Psoriatic arthritis may affect the knees, but other joints, skin, and nails are often involved. X-ray will show joint erosion and new bone formation.
  • • Option B. Psoriatic arthritis.
  • • Option C. Osteonecrosis. Death of bone tissue due to impaired blood supply. Pain and limited joint mobility are common. X-ray may show normal or non-specific changes.
  • • Option C. Osteonecrosis.
  • • Option D. Gout. Inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of urate crystals in joints. Sudden onset of severe pain, swelling, and redness in the affected joint (usually the big toe). X-ray shows joint space narrowing, tophi may be visible.
  • • Option D. Gout.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteoarthritis of knee commonly presents with symptoms of knee pain, pain on climbing stairs or knee bending, crepitus on knee movement, severe restriction of movement. X-ray findings in OA may include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.
  • ➤ Osteoarthritis of knee commonly presents with symptoms of knee pain, pain on climbing stairs or knee bending, crepitus on knee movement, severe restriction of movement.
  • ➤ X-ray findings in OA may include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

questions.text: All of the following are radiological features of Rheumatoid arthritis except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Fibrous ankyloses

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Decreased Joint space. In RA, joint space narrowing is a common finding due to cartilage destruction and erosion.
  • • Option A. Decreased Joint space.
  • • Option B. Articular Erosion. Erosions of joint surfaces are a hallmark of RA.
  • • Option B. Articular Erosion.
  • • Option C. Periarticular Osteopenia. Periarticular osteopenia, or bone density reduction around affected joints, is commonly seen in RA.
  • • Option C. Periarticular Osteopenia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Radiographic features of Rheumatoid arthritis is joint space narrowing, articular erosion and periarticular osteopenia. While joint stiffness and ankylosis can occur in RA, the more common form is bony ankylosis rather than fibrous ankylosis.
  • ➤ Radiographic features of Rheumatoid arthritis is joint space narrowing, articular erosion and periarticular osteopenia.
  • ➤ Radiographic features of Rheumatoid arthritis is joint space narrowing, articular erosion and periarticular osteopenia.
  • ➤ While joint stiffness and ankylosis can occur in RA, the more common form is bony ankylosis rather than fibrous ankylosis.

questions.text: True about ankylosing spondylitis is/are: Pain relieves on rest Association with HLA B-27 Enthesitis may occur 30% cases have acute posterior uveitis Cardiac conduction defect may present

questions.text: True about reactive arthritis is/are: Triad of arthritis, Urethritis and Conjunctivitis is seen Hyperkeratotic lesions on palms & soles are seen It is related to infections by chlamydia, shigella Anterior Uveitis is seen
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are correct

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis caused by bacterial infection from chlamydia and shigella. It involves a triad of arthritis, urethritis and conjunctivitis, which are classical of this condition. The most common ocular manifestation seen is the anterior uveitis. The most common musculoskeletal manifestations are the oligoarthritis involving the lower extremities, lumbar spine and the SI joint; and enthesitis in the Achilles tendon. The most common dermatological manifestation is the presence of hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and the soles.
  • ➤ Reactive arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis caused by bacterial infection from chlamydia and shigella.

  • ➤ The most common musculoskeletal manifestations are the oligoarthritis involving the lower extremities, lumbar spine and the SI joint; and enthesitis in the Achilles tendon.
  • ➤ The most common dermatological manifestation is the presence of hyperkeratotic lesions on the palms and the soles.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man had H/o of back pain since 3 months. ESR is raised. He also has dorsolumbar tenderness on examination and mild restriction of chest movements. On X-ray, syndesmophytes are present in vertebrae. Diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ankylosing hyperostosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis is present in young age group. Sacroiliitis is always present. Chest expansion is marked but not reliable in elderly. ESR will be high. Syndesmophytes will be present. Lumbar spine is more commonly involved.
  • • Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis.
  • • Option B. Degenerative osteoarthritis of spine. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of cartilage in joints, leading to pain and stiffness. It is more commonly associated with aging and wear and tear on joints. Upper cervical and lumbar spine are more commonly involved and are accompanied with radicular symptoms.
  • • Option B. Degenerative osteoarthritis of spine.
  • • Option D. Lumbar canal stenosis . Lumbar canal stenosis involves the narrowing of the spinal canal in the lumbar (lower back) region, which can lead to compression of the spinal cord and nerves. Symptoms may include back pain, leg pain, and neurogenic claudication (pain and weakness in the legs during walking). While lumbar canal stenosis can cause back pain, the presence of syndesmophytes and the inflammatory nature of the symptoms in the given case make ankylosing hyperostosis a more relevant diagnosis.
  • • Option D. Lumbar canal stenosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given complaints of the patient of increased ESR, dosrolumbar region pain and tenderness with mildly restricted chest movements and, the elder age group of the patient are suggestive of presence of ankylosing hyperostosis, which is different from ankylosing spondylitis.
  • ➤ The given complaints of the patient of increased ESR, dosrolumbar region pain and tenderness with mildly restricted chest movements and, the elder age group of the patient are suggestive of presence of ankylosing hyperostosis, which is different from ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Pencil-in-cup deformity is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Psoriatic arthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the joints. The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is not a classic feature of RA. Instead, RA is often associated with joint erosions, synovial inflammation, and deformities like ulnar deviation of the digits with radial deviation of the wrist, swan neck deformity, boutonniere deformity of the fingers.
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option B. Ankylosing spondylitis . Ankylosing spondylitis is a type of inflammatory arthritis that mainly affects the spine. The hands are not commonly involved in ankylosing spondylitis. Deformities like bamboo spine, dagger sign, trolley track sign are seen in the spine in the advanced stages of the disease.
  • • Option B. Ankylosing spondylitis
  • • a. Trolley track sign; b. Bamboo spine; c. Dagger sign
  • • a. Trolley track sign; b. Bamboo spine; c. Dagger sign
  • • Option C. AVN . Avascular necrosis is the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply. It can occur in various joints. AVN is typically associated with bone collapse and joint destruction. With the advancement of the necrosis, flattening of the femoral head can become evident on a plain radiograph.
  • • Option C. AVN

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is a classic radiological finding in psoriatic arthritis. It refers to erosive changes at the joint margins, resembling a pencil eroding into the cup-like joint space.
  • ➤ The "pencil-in-cup" deformity is a classic radiological finding in psoriatic arthritis.
  • ➤ It refers to erosive changes at the joint margins, resembling a pencil eroding into the cup-like joint space.

questions.text: Drug of choice for the treatment of acute gout in patients in whom NSAIDs are contraindicated is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Colchicine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Allopurinol. Allopurinol is not typically used for the treatment of acute gout attacks. It is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor and is primarily used for long-term management to lower uric acid levels in the blood, preventing the formation of urate crystals. Allopurinol is more commonly indicated for chronic gout treatment rather than for immediate relief during an acute attack.
  • • Option B. Allopurinol.
  • • Option C. Xyloric acid. Xyloric acid is not typically used for the treatment of acute gout attack.
  • • Option C.
  • • Xyloric acid.
  • • Option D. Paracetamol . Paracetamol (acetaminophen) is a pain reliever but is generally not the first-line choice for the treatment of acute gout attacks.
  • • Option D. Paracetamol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory medication that is effective in the treatment of acute gout attacks. It works by inhibiting the inflammatory response to urate crystals, reducing pain and inflammation. Colchicine is commonly used when NSAIDs are contraindicated or not well-tolerated.
  • ➤ Colchicine is an anti-inflammatory medication that is effective in the treatment of acute gout attacks.
  • ➤ It works by inhibiting the inflammatory response to urate crystals, reducing pain and inflammation.
  • ➤ Colchicine is commonly used when NSAIDs are contraindicated or not well-tolerated.

questions.correct_answer: A. Abrupt increase in serum urate levels is a more common cause for acute gout than an abrupt fall in urate levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Abrupt increase in serum urate levels is a more common cause for acute gout than an abrupt fall in urate levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Patient may be asymptomatic with high serum uric acid for years. Patients with elevated serum uric acid levels may remain asymptomatic for years before experiencing their first gout attack. Not everyone with hyperuricemia develops gout, and factors such as genetics, diet, and comorbidities play a role in the manifestation of gout.
  • • Option B. Patient may be asymptomatic with high serum uric acid for years.

Higher levels of serum uric acid increase the risk of urate crystal deposition in joints, leading to gouty arthritis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with urine darkening on standing, joint stiffness, and pigment deposition in joints. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alkaptonuria

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Phenylketonuria. Phenylketonuria is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, leading to the accumulation of phenylalanine in the blood. If not managed early, it can result in intellectual disabilities. Reduced Tyr can cause decreased melanin synthesis and light skin and hair. Signs and symptoms of the disease that become more pronounced when untreated include delayed developmental milestones, microcephaly, hypopigmentation, hyperactivity/behavior problems, seizures, and a musty odor to skin and urine. PKU is not associated with urine darkening on standing or pigment deposition in joints.
  • • Option A. Phenylketonuria.
  • • Option B. Tyrosinemia. Tyrosinemia is a group of rare genetic disorders characterized by the accumulation of tyrosine in the body. There are different types of tyrosinemia, and they can affect the liver, kidneys, and nervous system. However, like PKU, tyrosinemia is not typically associated with urine darkening or pigment deposition in joints.
  • • Option B. Tyrosinemia.
  • • Option D. Hemosiderin deposition. Hemosiderin is a pigment derived from hemoglobin breakdown and is typically seen in conditions involving chronic bleeding or iron overload. While hemosiderin deposition can cause discoloration of tissues, it's less likely to present with urine darkening and joint stiffness compared to alkaptonuria.
  • • Option D. Hemosiderin deposition.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid. This acid, when exposed to air, darkens and causes urine to turn dark upon standing.
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the deficiency of the enzyme homogentisate 1,2-dioxygenase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid.

questions.text: The pathognomonic finding in pseudogout is:
questions.explanation:

Instead, it may be more associated with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or other autoimmune disorders.
  • • Option B. Polyarthritis with urinary sediment.
  • • Option C. Juxta-articular osteopenia. Juxta-articular osteopenia, or decreased bone density near joints, is not a pathognomonic finding for pseudogout. It may be seen in various joint conditions, including inflammatory arthritis, but it is not specific to pseudogout.
  • • Option C.
  • • Juxta-articular osteopenia.
  • • Option D. Bone spurs . Bone spurs, also known as osteophytes, are bony outgrowths that can develop on the edges of joints. While pseudogout can contribute to joint damage and degeneration, the presence of bone spurs is not pathognomonic for pseudogout.
  • • Option D. Bone spurs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

These crystals are rhomboid-shaped and exhibit positive birefringence under polarized light microscopy. The identification of CPPD crystals in synovial fluid is a key diagnostic feature of pseudogout.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about osteoarthritis?

options.label: D
options.text: Narrowing of the joint space occurs

questions.explanation:

  • • Option B. Most common disease of joints
  • • Option C. Affects shoulder joint . True. While osteoarthritis is more commonly associated with weight-bearing joints like the knees and hips, it can affect any joint in the body, including the shoulder. In the shoulder joint, osteoarthritis may lead to pain, stiffness, and reduced range of motion.
  • • Option C. Affects shoulder joint
  • • Option D. Narrowing of the joint space . True. Radiographically, osteoarthritis is characterized by the narrowing of the joint space. As the cartilage in the joint wears away, the space between the bones decreases. This narrowing is a hallmark feature seen on X-rays in individuals with osteoarthritis.

questions.text: What is true about Articular cartilage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Has no nerve supply

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Very vascular structure. False. Articular cartilage is avascular i.e., it lacks blood vessels. It relies on diffusion from the synovial fluid to obtain nutrients and oxygen. The absence of blood vessels contributes to the limited regenerative capacity of articular cartilage.
  • • Option A. Very vascular structure.
  • • Option B. Surrounded by thick perichondrium. False. Articular cartilage does not have a perichondrium. Perichondrium is a dense connective tissue layer that surrounds most cartilage types, but articular cartilage lacks this outer layer. This absence contributes to the limited ability of articular cartilage to repair and regenerate.
  • • Option B. Surrounded by thick perichondrium.
  • • Option D. Fibrocartilage . False. Articular cartilage is predominantly hyaline cartilage, not fibrocartilage. Fibrocartilage is a different type of cartilage that contains more collagen fibres and is found in structures like the intervertebral discs and certain joint structures.
  • • Option D. Fibrocartilage

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Articular cartilage is avascular and aneural i.e., it lacks blood vessels and nerves.

Explanation:

Diagnosis of RA is based on clinical features, laboratory tests (such as rheumatoid factor and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibodies), and imaging studies. The 1987 ACR/EULAR classification criteria is used for RA diagnosis. It requires presence of at least 4 out of 7 symptoms for at least 3 months.

Arthritis of 3 or more joint areas, observed by a physician simultaneously, have soft tissue swelling or joint effusion, not just bony over growth. The 14 possible joint areas involved are right or left PIP, MCP, wrist, elbow, knee, ankle and MTP joints. Arthritis of hand joints, e.g. wrist, MP or PIP joints. Symmetrical arthritis. Rheumatoid nodules (Pathognomonic): Subcutaneous nodules over bony prominences, extensor surfaces or juxta-articular region. Serum rheumatoid factor. Radiological changes : bony erosion or unequivocal bony decalcification, periarticular osteoporosis and narrowing of articular (joint) space.

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a type of inflammatory arthritis that mainly affects the spine, causing stiffness, pain, and eventually fusion of the vertebrae. Diagnosis of AS involves clinical features, imaging studies (like X-rays showing syndesmophytes), and sometimes blood tests. A diagnosis of AS can usually be confirmed if an X-ray shows sacroiliitis and there is at least 1 of the following :

  • • Option D. Reactive synovitis. Reactive synovitis refers to inflammation of the synovial membrane in response to an infection elsewhere in the body, often in the gastrointestinal or genitourinary tract. It is not a specific term used for a well-defined rheumatological condition. Diagnosis involves assessing the clinical context, including symptoms and potential triggers of the inflammation. According to American College of Rheumatology, there are 2 major and 2 minor diagnostic guidelines of reactive arthritis. Major guidelines includes a symmetric oligo or monoarthritis involving lower extremities, and either enteritis or urethritis symptoms preceding the onset of arthritis by a time interval of 3 days to 6 weeks. Minor guidelines includes presence of a triggering infection as evidenced by culture positivity, and presence of persistent synovial involvement.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male underwent total hip replacement surgery due to severe osteoarthritis. The surgery went uneventful, but on 3 rd post-operative day, he started complaining of breathlessness which worsens on increase in activity, chest discomfort. Lab investigations reveals raised d-dimer levels. What is the definitive management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thrombolysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Bronchodilators. Bronchodilators are primarily used in conditions such as asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) to relieve airway constriction. In the context of a pulmonary embolism, bronchodilators would not be the first-line treatment, as the primary issue is a blood clot affecting blood flow to the lungs.
  • • Option B. Bronchodilators.
  • • Option C. Steroids. Steroids are generally not the primary treatment for a pulmonary embolism. They would not address the underlying cause of the symptoms, which is likely a blood clot. Steroids might be used for certain inflammatory conditions but are not indicated as a definitive treatment for pulmonary embolism.
  • • Option C. Steroids.
  • • Options D. Oxygen . Oxygen is often given to patients experiencing breathlessness or hypoxia (low oxygen levels). While providing oxygen can support the patient's respiratory function, it does not directly address the underlying cause of a pulmonary embolism. Oxygen is supportive care and is often used while other definitive treatments, such as anticoagulation, are initiated.
  • • Options D. Oxygen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thrombolysis is commonly used in cases of severe pulmonary embolism where there is a significant compromise of blood flow to the lungs. Thrombolysis aims to rapidly break down the clot and restore normal blood circulation.

questions.text: Nutrient and oxygen reach the chondrocytes across perichondrium by:
questions.explanation:

Since articular cartilage is an avascular structure, it gets its nutrients from the blood supply of the perichondrium. So nutrients and oxygen reach the chondrocytes across perichondrium by the process of diffusion.

questions.text: All of the following statements about synovial fluid are true, except:

options.label: A

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Follows Non-Newtonian fluid kinetics. True. Synovial fluid exhibits non-Newtonian behaviour, i.e., its viscosity changes with the rate of shear applied. This property allows the fluid to become less viscous during joint movement, facilitating smooth articulation.
  • • Option B. Follows Non-Newtonian fluid kinetics.
  • • Option C. Contains hyaluronic acid. True. Synovial fluid contains hyaluronic acid, a glycosaminoglycan that contributes to the lubrication and viscosity of the fluid. Hyaluronic acid helps in maintaining the integrity of the synovial fluid film on joint surfaces.
  • • Option C. Contains hyaluronic acid.
  • • Option D. Viscosity is variable. True. The viscosity of synovial fluid is variable and influenced by factors such as hydration, the presence of hyaluronic acid, and the overall health of the joint. Viscosity tends to increase with rest and decrease with joint movement.
  • • Option D. Viscosity is variable.

  • ➤ It contains hyaluronic acid.
  • ➤ Its viscosity is variable.
  • ➤ It is an ultra-dialysate of blood plasma transudated from synovial capillaries to which hyaluronic acid protein complex (mucin) has been added by synovial B cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about changes in articular cartilage with aging is not true?

options.label: C
options.text: Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is increased

options.label: D
options.text: Total water content of cartilage is decrease

questions.correct_answer: C. Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is increased
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is increased

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Total proteoglycan content is decreased. True. Proteoglycans are the molecules in the extracellular fluid that help maintain its structure and function. With ageing, the total proteolytic enzyme degradation decreases with increasing age.
  • • Option A. Total proteoglycan content is decreased.
  • • Option B. Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased. True. With aging, there is a decrease in the synthesis of proteoglycans by chondrocytes. This reduction in synthesis contributes to the decline in total proteoglycan content observed in aging cartilage.
  • • Option B. Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased. True.
  • • Option D. Total water content of cartilage is decreased . True. With aging, the total water content of the cartilage is decreased. In osteoarthritis, it is increased, but decreased in advanced OA.
  • • Option D. Total water content of cartilage is decreased

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is normal with ageing. Total proteoglycan content is decreased. Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased. Total water content of cartilage is decreased.
  • ➤ Enzymatic degradation of proteoglycans is normal with ageing.
  • ➤ Total proteoglycan content is decreased.
  • ➤ Synthesis of proteoglycans is decreased.
  • ➤ Total water content of cartilage is decreased.

questions.text: After knee replacement surgery, proprioceptors of joints are altered. Effect is:

options.label: B
options.text: Complete loss of sensation at joint position at resting stage

options.label: C
options.text: Loss of sensation of joint position at dynamic stage

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Normal movement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Complete loss of sensation at joint position at resting stage. Complete loss of sensation at the joint position, particularly at the resting stage could result in challenges for the patient in maintaining a sense of joint position when the knee is at rest.
  • • Option B. Complete loss of sensation at joint position at resting stage.
  • • Option C. Loss of sensation of joints position at dynamic stage. This suggests that the alteration in proprioception is more prominent during dynamic movements rather than at rest.
  • • Option C. Loss of sensation of joints position at dynamic stage.
  • • Option D. All types of sensation lost. T his implies a complete loss of sensation, which would include not only proprioception but also other types of sensory feedback.
  • • Option D. All types of sensation lost.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • After knee replacement surgery, proprioceptors of joints are altered and the effect will occur on Normal movements. Normal movement may be retained.
  • • After knee replacement surgery, proprioceptors of joints are altered and the effect will occur on Normal movements. Normal movement may be retained.

questions.text: Metal on metal articulation should be avoided in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Young female

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Osteonecrosis. Osteonecrosis is the death of bone tissue due to a lack of blood supply. Metal-on-metal articulation is not specifically contraindicated in osteonecrosis.
  • • Option A. Osteonecrosis.
  • • Option C. Inflammatory arthritis. Metal-on-metal articulation is generally not recommended in patients with inflammatory arthritis, such as rheumatoid arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis patients may have an increased risk of adverse reactions to metal debris, making alternative implant materials, like ceramic or polyethylene, more suitable.
  • • Option C. Inflammatory arthritis.
  • • Option D. Revision surgery. Metal-on-metal articulation is sometimes used in revision surgery, but its use has declined due to concerns about metal ion release. In revision surgeries, the choice of implant material depends on various factors, including the reason for revision and the condition of the surrounding bone.
  • • Option D. Revision surgery.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metal-on-metal articulation is often avoided in young, active females due to concerns about wear and the potential for metal ion release. This patient population may have a longer life expectancy, and concerns about the long-term effects of metal ions make alternative implant materials more favourable. They are also avoided in females in a child bearing age as the metal ions can cross the placenta, causing damage to the fetus.
  • ➤ Metal-on-metal articulation is often avoided in young, active females due to concerns about wear and the potential for metal ion release.
  • ➤ This patient population may have a longer life expectancy, and concerns about the long-term effects of metal ions make alternative implant materials more favourable.
  • ➤ They are also avoided in females in a child bearing age as the metal ions can cross the placenta, causing damage to the fetus.

questions.text: A patient developed breathlessness and chest pain on second postoperative after a total hip replacement. Echocardiography showed right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Acute MI. Acute MI refers to the sudden death of part of the heart muscle due to a lack of blood supply. Symptoms include chest pain, shortness of breath, and can sometimes lead to complications such as heart failure with right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation, is more indicative of a condition affecting the pulmonary circulation rather than a primary cardiac event. Myocardial infarction can occur after hip replacement surgery but it is less commonly seen than pulmonary thromboembolism.
  • • Option A. Acute MI.
  • • Option C. Hypotensive shock. Hypotensive shock refers to a state of insufficient blood flow to meet the body's needs, resulting in low blood pressure. While it can cause symptoms like breathlessness, it usually doesn't present with right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography. Total knee arthroplasty can cause severe blood loss that can lead to hypovolemic shock.
  • • Option C. Hypotensive shock.
  • • Option D. Cardiac Tamponade. Cardiac tamponade is a condition where fluid accumulates in the pericardial sac, compressing the heart. This can lead to symptoms such as chest pain and shortness of breath. However, it typically presents with other signs, and echocardiography in cardiac tamponade may reveal features like diastolic collapse of the right atrium and right ventricle, rather than right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation. This condition is rarely seen, but can be seen after posterior pedicle screw fixation of the spine.
  • • Option D. Cardiac Tamponade.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, usually originating from the legs (deep vein thrombosis), travels to the lungs and blocks a pulmonary artery. Symptoms can include sudden onset of breathlessness, chest pain, and in severe cases, right heart strain as evidenced by right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography. This is seen as a common complication of total hip replacement surgeries.
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, usually originating from the legs (deep vein thrombosis), travels to the lungs and blocks a pulmonary artery.
  • ➤ Symptoms can include sudden onset of breathlessness, chest pain, and in severe cases, right heart strain as evidenced by right ventricular dilatation and tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography.
  • ➤ This is seen as a common complication of total hip replacement surgeries.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of death after total hip replacement?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pulmonary embolism

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Infections. Infection is a potential complication after total hip replacement, but it is not typically the most common cause of death. Infections can lead to local complications, such as joint infections (septic arthritis), which may require surgical intervention. Systemic spread leading to death is less common.
  • • Option A. Infections.
  • • Option B. Deep Vein Thrombosis. It is a significant concern after total hip replacement due to the risk of blood clots forming in the deep veins, usually in the legs. While Deep Vein Thrombosis itself is a serious condition, the most life-threatening complication arises when a clot breaks loose and travels to the lungs, causing a pulmonary embolism (PE).
  • • Option B. Deep Vein Thrombosis.
  • • Option D. Pneumonia. Pneumonia, an infection of the lungs, can occur after surgery due to factors such as immobility, anesthesia, and decreased lung function. While pneumonia is a concern, it is generally less common as the primary cause of death after total hip replacement compared to complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • • Option D. Pneumonia.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, often originating from the deep veins of the legs, travels to the lungs, causing a blockage in the pulmonary arteries. This can be a severe and life-threatening complication, especially after orthopedic surgeries where immobility and surgical trauma contribute to the risk of clot formation.
  • ➤ Pulmonary embolism occurs when a blood clot, often originating from the deep veins of the legs, travels to the lungs, causing a blockage in the pulmonary arteries.
  • ➤ This can be a severe and life-threatening complication, especially after orthopedic surgeries where immobility and surgical trauma contribute to the risk of clot formation.

questions.text: Aseptic loosening in cemented total hip replacement occurs as a result of hypersensitivity response to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High density polyethylene debris

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Titanium debris. Titanium is a biocompatible material commonly used in orthopedic implants. While titanium debris can be generated from the wear and tear of the implant, it is not typically associated with aseptic loosening. Titanium is generally well-tolerated by the body, and adverse reactions to titanium debris are uncommon.
  • • Option A. Titanium debris.
  • • Option C. N, N-Dimethyltryptamine. N, N-Dimethyltryptamine (DMT) is a naturally occurring psychedelic compound, and it is not relevant to hip replacement or aseptic loosening. It is not used in implant materials, and there is no association between DMT and hip replacement complications.
  • • Option C. N, N-Dimethyltryptamine.
  • • Option D. Free Radicals. Free radicals are reactive molecules that can contribute to oxidative stress and tissue damage. While oxidative stress can play a role in the inflammatory response to wear debris, the direct association of free radicals as a cause of aseptic loosening is not as specific as the association with the wear debris itself.
  • • Option D. Free Radicals.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Particles of metal (titanium, nickel, chromium, etc.), cement (PMMA) and polyethylene all can produce periprosthetic osteolysis (aseptic loosening). Polyethylene particles appear to be the major particles causing the damage. Since high density polyethylene is used in the acetabular component of the implant, its wearing out and friction generates small particles that can cause inflammatory response in tissues, leading to loosening of the implant.
  • ➤ Particles of metal (titanium, nickel, chromium, etc.), cement (PMMA) and polyethylene all can produce periprosthetic osteolysis (aseptic loosening).
  • ➤ Polyethylene particles appear to be the major particles causing the damage.
  • ➤ Since high density polyethylene is used in the acetabular component of the implant, its wearing out and friction generates small particles that can cause inflammatory response in tissues, leading to loosening of the implant.

questions.text: Heberden's nodes are seen in:

options.label: A
options.text: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints

options.label: B
options.text: Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints

options.label: C
options.text: Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints

options.label: D
options.text: Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint

questions.correct_answer: A. Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints. Osteoarthritis of the PIP joint of the hand presents as Bouchard’s nodes.
  • • Option B. Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints.
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1 st CMC joint of the hand i.e. the base of the thumb presents as the swan neck deformity of the thumb. This involves hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the MCP joint with a consequent loss of thumb mobility and pinch.
  • • Option C.
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint.
  • • Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints. RA of the DIP joint may present as swan neck deformity i.e., hyperextension of PIP joint and compensatory flexion of the DIP joint.
  • • Option D.
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Heberden's nodes are a classic feature of osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the DIP joints.
  • ➤ Heberden's nodes are a classic feature of osteoarthritis, particularly affecting the DIP joints.

questions.text: Bouchard's nodes are seen in:

options.label: A
options.text: Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints

options.label: B

Ans. B) Osteoarthritis of the proximal interphalangeal joints

  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1st carpometacarpal joint. Rheumatoid arthritis of the 1 st CMC joint of the hand i.e. the base of the thumb presents as the swan neck deformity of the thumb. This involves hyperextension of the interphalangeal joint and flexion of the MCP joint with a consequent loss of thumb mobility and pinch.
  • • Option C.

  • • Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis of the distal interphalangeal joints. RA of the DIP joint may present as swan neck deformity i.e., hyperextension of PIP joint and compensatory flexion of the DIP joint.

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which one of the following bursae always communicates with knee joint cavity?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Suprapatellar

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Prepatellar. It is s ituated in front of the patella, between the skin and the patellar ligament. It reduces friction between the skin and the patella during knee movement. It does not communicate directly with the knee joint cavity. It is a separate bursa.
  • • Option A. Prepatellar.
  • • Option C. Superficial infrapatellar. Found just below the skin and above the patellar ligament, it aids in reducing friction between the skin and the patellar ligament. It does not directly communicate with the knee joint cavity.
  • • Option C. Superficial infrapatellar.
  • • Option D. Deep infrapatellar. Situated deep within the knee joint, beneath the patellar ligament, it helps to protect the joint and absorb shocks during movements. It does not directly communicate with the knee joint cavity.
  • • Option D. Deep infrapatellar.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Located above the patella, between the quadriceps tendon and the femur, suprapatellar bursa helps in reducing friction between the quadriceps tendon and the distal femur during knee movements. It communicates with the knee joint cavity. An opening called the " suprapatellar pouch " extends into the joint.
  • ➤ Located above the patella, between the quadriceps tendon and the femur, suprapatellar bursa helps in reducing friction between the quadriceps tendon and the distal femur during knee movements.
  • ➤ It communicates with the knee joint cavity.
  • ➤ An opening called the " suprapatellar pouch " extends into the joint.
  • ➤ suprapatellar pouch

questions.text: A 60 years old female has a previous case history of fever, fatigue, weight loss and polyarthralgia. She had morning stiffness and bilateral hand pain. The radiological findings are given below. What may be your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rheumatoid arthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and the underlying bone. X-ray findings in osteoarthritis include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis. Osteoarthritis is not associated with systemic symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss.
  • • Option A. Osteoarthritis.
  • • Option C. Gout. Gout is an inflammatory arthritis caused by the deposition of urate crystals in joints, leading to sudden attacks of pain and swelling. In chronic gout, X-ray may show joint erosions and the presence of tophi (deposits of urate crystals). Gout typically presents as acute, intermittent attacks rather than chronic, progressive joint involvement.
  • • Option C. Gout.
  • • Option D. Psoriatic Arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. May include joint erosions and new bone formation (ankylosis). Psoriatic arthritis often involves the axial skeleton and may have distinct radiological features compared to RA.
  • • Option D. Psoriatic Arthritis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of symptoms like fever, weight loss, fatigue and the involvement of multiple joints, including the hands, is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Radiological findings, such as joint erosions and periarticular osteopenia, are commonly associated with RA.
  • ➤ The combination of symptoms like fever, weight loss, fatigue and the involvement of multiple joints, including the hands, is consistent with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
  • ➤ Radiological findings, such as joint erosions and periarticular osteopenia, are commonly associated with RA.

questions.text: Which of the following is the difference between Rheumatoid arthritis and osteoarthritis?

options.label: B
options.text: Systemic symptoms are seen in osteoarthritis

options.label: C
options.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is uncommon in hands and feet

questions.correct_answer: A. Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis. True. Osteoarthritis is characterized by the presence of osteophytes which are the osteocartilaginous outgrowth at the joint margins where the synovium attaches to the edge of the articular cartilage and merges with the periosteum.
  • • Option A. Osteophytes are seen in osteoarthritis.
  • • Option B. Systemic symptoms are seen in osteoarthritis . False. Systemic symptoms such as fever, fatigue are seen in rheumatoid arthritis and are not associated with osteoarthritis.
  • • Option B. Systemic symptoms are seen in osteoarthritis
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis is uncommon in hands and feet . False. Rheumatoid arthritis often affects small joints, including those in the hands and feet. Osteoarthritis is more commonly seen in the large joints like the knees and the hips.
  • • Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis is uncommon in hands and feet
  • • Option D. Osteoarthritis is an autoimmune disease . False. Osteoarthritis is not considered as an autoimmune disease. It is an age-related, mechanical, degenerative disease of the joints.
  • • Option D. Osteoarthritis is an autoimmune disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Osteophytes, also known as bone spurs , are commonly seen in osteoarthritis. They form at the joint margins as a result of the degeneration of cartilage and are a characteristic feature of OA and not RA.
  • ➤ Osteophytes, also known as bone spurs , are commonly seen in osteoarthritis. They form at the joint margins as a result of the degeneration of cartilage and are a characteristic feature of OA and not RA.
  • ➤ bone spurs

questions.text: Most specific antibody seen in RA is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anti CCP

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Rheumatoid factor. Rheumatoid factor is an antibody directed against the Fc portion of immunoglobulin G (IgG). It can be positive in a subset of RA patients, but its sensitivity and specificity are lower compared to anti-CCP antibodies.
  • • Option B. Rheumatoid factor.
  • • Option C. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies). Antinuclear antibodies target components of the cell nucleus. While ANA can be positive in a variety of autoimmune conditions, it is not specific to RA.
  • • Option C. ANA (Antinuclear Antibodies).
  • • Option D. Anti dsDNA antibodies. Anti-dsDNA antibodies target double-stranded DNA. Elevated levels of anti-dsDNA antibodies are often seen in SLE and are part of the criteria for diagnosing lupus.
  • • Option D. Anti dsDNA antibodies.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The anti-CCP, rheumatoid factor, ANA have a high specificity for RA, and their presence is often considered an important diagnostic marker, especially in the early stages of the disease. Out of the given options, Anti-CCP antibodies are the most specific marker for RA diagnosis.
  • ➤ The anti-CCP, rheumatoid factor, ANA have a high specificity for RA, and their presence is often considered an important diagnostic marker, especially in the early stages of the disease.
  • ➤ Out of the given options, Anti-CCP antibodies are the most specific marker for RA diagnosis.
  • ➤ Anti-CCP antibodies

questions.text: A middle aged female with rheumatoid arthritis on treatment develops upper motor neuron signs in her limbs. The investigation required to evaluate her further is:

options.label: A

questions.text: “Wind-swept deformity” is seen in:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Rickets

questions.text: A young male having pain with daily morning stiffness of spine for 30 minutes and reduced chest movements. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ankylosing spondylitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis. RA is a systemic autoimmune disease that primarily affects peripheral joints. Morning stiffness is common in RA but typically lasts for a shorter duration compared to AS. While RA can affect the cervical spine, it is not the primary site of involvement, and chest movements are not typically significantly reduced.
  • • Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option C. Gouty Arthritis . Gout primarily affects peripheral joints and is characterized by recurrent attacks of inflammatory arthritis. Morning stiffness is less characteristic of gout, and spine involvement is not a typical feature.
  • • Option C. Gouty Arthritis
  • • Option D. Osteoarthritis. OA is a degenerative joint disease that commonly affects weight-bearing joints. Morning stiffness in OA is usually brief and improves with movement. While OA can affect the spine, the described pattern of morning stiffness and reduced chest movements is not typical for OA.
  • • Option D. Osteoarthritis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy characterized by inflammatory back pain, morning stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes, and reduced chest movements due to involvement of the spine and costovertebral joints.
  • ➤ Ankylosing spondylitis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy characterized by inflammatory back pain, morning stiffness lasting more than 30 minutes, and reduced chest movements due to involvement of the spine and costovertebral joints.

questions.text: A young man complaints of pain in lower back. His X-rays are shown below. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Ankylosing Spondylitis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option B. Spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis is a condition where one vertebra slips forward over the vertebra below it. On X-ray, spondylolisthesis may appear as a forward displacement of one vertebra over another, and it is often associated with specific changes like "step-off" or "spondylolytic defects."
  • • Option B. Spondylolisthesis.
  • • Option C. Paget’s disease. Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder that results in enlarged and misshapen bones. X-rays of the spine may show areas of increased bone density, presenting as ivory vertebra.
  • • Option C. Paget’s disease.
  • • Option D. Osteoporosis. Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by weakened bones with an increased risk of fractures. Osteoporosis in the spinal x-ray can be seen as fish mouth vertebra.
  • • Option D. Osteoporosis.

questions.text: Arthroscopy is contraindicated in:
questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Chronic joint disease.
  • • Option B. Loose Bodies. Arthroscopy is commonly used to address loose bodies within a joint. Loose bodies are fragments of cartilage or bone that may interfere with joint movement and cause pain. Arthroscopy allows for the visualization and removal of these loose bodies, helping to improve joint function and alleviate symptoms.
  • • Option B. Loose Bodies.
  • • Option D. Meniscal tear. Arthroscopy is often used to diagnose and treat meniscal tears. In this procedure, a surgeon can visualize the inside of the joint, identify the torn meniscus, and often repair or trim the damaged tissue. Arthroscopy is a common and effective method for managing meniscal tears.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

It is characterized by inflammation, fusion of joints, and eventual bone formation. Charcot's joint is not commonly associated with ankylosing spondylitis. Ankylosing spondylitis has distinct features, such as axial involvement and bamboo spine, which are different from the characteristics of Charcot's joint.

questions.text: Most common cause of neuropathic joints is:

It leads to sensory ataxia, impaired proprioception, and can result in Charcot joints. The loss of sensation and coordination contributes to the development of joint damage.

The given complaint of presence of the calcification in bilateral knees is characteristic of tumor calcinosis. In this rare condition, the serum calcium, PTH and ALP levels remains normal. Since, hyperphosphatemia is the primary defect in this condition, it is important to investigate the serum phosphate levels to rule out the condition.

questions.explanation:

  • • Option A. Rheumatoid Arthritis.
  • • Option C. Paget’s disease . Paget's disease of bone, also known as osteitis deformans is a chronic disorder that results in enlarged and deformed bones. It typically affects the spine, pelvis, long bones, and skull. Unlike Bechterew's Disease, Paget's disease involves abnormal bone remodelling, leading to increased bone density and potential deformities.
  • • Option C. Paget’s disease
  • • Option D. Osteopetrosis . Osteopetrosis or Albers-Schonber disease, is a rare genetic disorder characterized by abnormally dense bones. It results from impaired bone resorption, leading to increased bone mass. This condition can cause bone fractures, anemia, and neurological complications. Osteopetrosis is distinct from Bechterew's Disease, which is an inflammatory arthritis affecting the spine.
  • • Option D. Osteopetrosis

Affected knees may have very large effusions with warmth, but they are not particularly painful with range of motion or weight bearing. Baker’s cysts may be present in the knees.

It is typically associated with aging and wear and tear on the joints. Osteoarthritis is considerably more prevalent in the distal than the proximal interphalangeal joints. The soft tissue swelling around the DIP joint associated with osteophyte formation is called a Heberden node and that around the PIP joint is called a Bouchard node .

This can be seen in the context of dactylitis, a hallmark feature of psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: While performing a total hip replacement, the surgeon found destruction of the articular cartilage and multiple wedge-shaped subchondral depressions. What is this called?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Osteonecrosis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

In the context of joint replacement, periprosthetic osteolysis can occur due to the release of wear particles from the prosthetic components, triggering an inflammatory response. Over time, this can lead to the breakdown of bone around the implant.
  • • Option A. Osteolysis.
  • • Option B. Osteomyelitis. Osteomyelitis is an infection of the bone that can occur due to the introduction of bacteria. It can cause inflammation, destruction of bone tissue, and sometimes the formation of abscesses. Osteomyelitis can be caused by bacteria entering the bone through trauma, surgery, or the bloodstream.
  • • Option B. Osteomyelitis.
  • • Option D. Osteogenesis . Osteogenesis refers to the formation or production of new bone tissue. This process is crucial for bone development, repair, and remodeling. Osteoblasts are cells responsible for bone formation, and osteogenesis plays a role in maintaining bone density and strength.
  • • Option D. Osteogenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Destruction of articular cartilage and presence of the wedge-shaped subchondral depressions are characteristic of osteonecrosis, where impaired blood supply leads to the death of bone tissue.

  • • Option C. Performed through cancellous bone.
  • • Option D. Recurrence is a long term complication. True. Recurrence of deformity is a potential long-term complication of High Tibial Osteotomy. Over time, factors such as healing and remodelling can influence the achieved correction, and in some cases, recurrence of deformity may occur.

High Tibial Osteotomy is more commonly performed within a range of 5 to 15 degrees of correction. It is performed through the cutting of the cancellous bone. Recurrence of the deformity is a long-term complication, that is seen in about 5-30% cases.

questions.text: About Osteoarthritis, choose the correct statement: Thickening of synovial membrane is one of the earliest feature of the disease Weight bearing is a common etiology underlying ankle OA In India, knee OA is more common than hip OA Hip arthrodesis if done, can decrease the pain associated, but will cause a decrease in joint movement MCP joint is spared in OA
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4, 5

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Thickening of synovial membrane is one of the earliest feature of the disease . False. The earliest feature of the disease is the fibrillation, irregularity and focal erosion of the articular cartilage. Weight bearing is a common etiology underlying ankle OA . True. Several factors can contribute to the development of ankle OA, including injury, genetics, and mechanical stress. Weight bearing is a significant mechanical stressor on the ankle joint. Over time, repetitive loading and impact on the joint during weight-bearing activities can lead to wear and tear of the cartilage in the ankle joint, eventually resulting in the development of osteoarthritis in the ankle. In India, knee OA is more common than hip OA . True. Osteoarthritis of the knee is more commonly seen than that of the hip joint. Hip arthrodesis if done, can decrease the pain associated, but will cause a decrease in joint movement . True. Arthrodesis is another surgical intervention in cases of OA. It reduces the joint pain but sacrifices the joint's articular function, so it is performed on small joints, like wrists and ankles. MCP joint is spared in OA . True. MCP and wrist joint are spared in OA. DIP, PIP and 1 st CMC joint are commonly involved.

questions.text: Severe disability in primary osteoarthritis of hip is best managed by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Arthroplasty

Explanation:

  • • Explanation :
  • • Option A. Arthrodesis. Arthrodesis involves the surgical fusion of the hip joint, eliminating movement. Arthrodesis is not typically the first-line treatment for osteoarthritis of the hip, especially considering the desire to preserve hip function in daily activities. It may be considered in the severe OA of the ankle and the wrist joints.
  • • Option A. Arthrodesis.
  • • Option C. McMurray’s osteotomy . McMurray’s osteotomy is a surgical procedure involving the repositioning of the acetabulum to improve hip joint mechanics. It is not a commonly performed procedure for advanced osteoarthritis of the hip. It is done for the management of malunited femoral neck fracture or those fractures with non-union/delayed union.
  • • Option C. McMurray’s osteotomy
  • • Option D. Intra- articular hydrocortisone and physiotherapy. Intra-articular injections of corticosteroids may be used to reduce inflammation, and physiotherapy aims to improve joint function and strength. This option is more appropriate for managing symptoms and mild to moderate osteoarthritis. In severe cases with significant disability, more aggressive interventions like surgery may be required.
  • • Option D. Intra- articular hydrocortisone and physiotherapy.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arthroplasty, specifically total hip arthroplasty (THA) is a well-established and effective surgical intervention for severe osteoarthritis of the hip.

  • • Option D. High Tibial Osteotomy . High tibial osteotomy involves repositioning the upper part of the tibia to shift weight away from the damaged part of the knee joint. High tibial osteotomy is more commonly considered in cases where there is isolated medial compartment osteoarthritis and malalignment, and the patient is young.

questions.explanation:

Flexion at PIP joint and extension at DIP : This is true. In Boutonniere deformity, there is flexion at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint and extension at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Seen in cases of osteoarthritis : This is not typically associated with osteoarthritis. Boutonniere deformity is commonly seen in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, trauma, or congenital conditions affecting the extensor mechanism. Rupture of flexor tendon : This is incorrect. Boutonniere deformity is primarily caused by a rupture of the extensor tendon, not the flexor tendon.

  • • Option A. Most commonly involves the sacroiliac joints. True. Ankylosing spondylitis typically involves the sacroiliac joints, and inflammatory changes are commonly observed in this region.
  • • Option A.
  • • Most commonly involves the sacroiliac joints.
  • • Option B. Enthesitis is common. True. Enthesitis, inflammation at the sites where tendons or ligaments insert into the bone, is a characteristic feature of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • • Option B.
  • • Enthesitis is common.
  • • Option C. More common is males. True. Ankylosing spondylitis has a strong male predominance. The males of age 15-25 are more commonly affected.
  • • Option C.
  • • More common is males.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MRI is the most sensitive investigation to make a diagnosis of ankylosing spondylitis because is shows the inflammatory changes in the SI joint which is the most commonly involved joint in AS. While radiographic imaging, such as X-rays (roentgenogram), can reveal characteristic changes in the later stages of AS, it is not the most sensitive investigation, especially in the early stages. MRI is often more sensitive for detecting early inflammatory changes.

questions.text: False about treatment of Charcot’s joint in diabetes mellitus is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Total ankle replacement

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:

  • • Option B. Arthrodesis. Arthrodesis involves surgical fusion of a joint and is considered in cases of severe deformity or instability in Charcot joint.

questions.text: Martel’s sign is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Gouty arthritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Rheumatoid arthritis. It is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the synovium (lining of the joints), leading to joint inflammation, pain, and eventually joint damage. Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with Z-deformity, swan neck deformity, Boutonniere deformities of the fingers, windswept deformity of the toes, and hammer toe.
  • • Option A.
  • • Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • • Option B. Osteoarthritis. Osteoarthritis is a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone changes. Osteoarthritis is associated with heberden’s and bouchard’s nodes in the fingers.
  • • Option B.
  • • Osteoarthritis.
  • • Option D. Ochronosis. Ochronosis is a metabolic disorder associated with the accumulation of homogentisic acid. It is associated with skin and bone discoloration.
  • • Option D.
  • • Ochronosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tophi in the gouty arthritis appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges. This is called Martel’s or G’ sign .
  • ➤ Tophi in the gouty arthritis appear as characteristic punched out cysts or deep erosions with over hanging bony edges.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with frequent attacks of joint pain underwent an X-ray showing soft tissue swelling. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Parathyroid adenoma. Parathyroid adenoma is a benign tumor of the parathyroid gland that can lead to overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH). Elevated levels of PTH can result in increased calcium levels in the blood, leading to conditions like hyperparathyroidism. While hyperparathyroidism can affect the bones and joints, it typically does not present with the sudden, acute joint pain. The common symptomatic osseous findings include subperiosteal and subchondral joint resorption, acro-osteolysis, the salt-and-pepper skull, the brown tumors, and osteopenia.
  • • Option B. Parathyroid adenoma.
  • • Option C. Psoriasis . Psoriasis is a chronic autoimmune skin condition that can also affect the joints, leading to a condition known as psoriatic arthritis. Psoriatic arthritis involves inflammation of the joints and surrounding tissues, often accompanied by skin symptoms like psoriasis plaques. In the foot, there are periarticular and subarticular erosive changes in the MTP joints and the IP joints. Subchondral sclerosis and erosions as well as marginal osteophytes are also present There is soft tissue swelling in relation to the involved joints.
  • • Option C. Psoriasis
  • • Option D. RA. Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic autoimmune disease that primarily affects the synovium (lining of the joints), leading to joint inflammation, pain, and eventual joint damage. RA typically presents with symmetrical joint involvement and can affect multiple joints throughout the body. Radiologically, there is soft tissue swelling, joint effusion, juxta-articular osteopenia, bone erosions, joint space narrowing, sclerosis or osteophytes.
  • • Option D. RA.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the x-ray finding of tophi in the toe are diagnostic of Gout in the patient. The sudden and episodic nature of the joint pain, along with the presence of soft tissue swelling, is characteristic of gout attacks.
  • ➤ The given symptoms and the x-ray finding of tophi in the toe are diagnostic of Gout in the patient.
  • ➤ The sudden and episodic nature of the joint pain, along with the presence of soft tissue swelling, is characteristic of gout attacks.
